  • FameLab Works!

Before it I had never considered a career in science communication or even been aware that such a field existed.

After Famelab I set up my own small science communication company "Ready, Steady, Science" which is still going from strength to strength and last year helped inspire over six thousand school children.

As a result of being seen at the Cheltenham Famelab final I started to work as a presenter for the documentary “Inside Nature’s Giants”

Simon Watt – Evolutionary Biology – 2005 Finalist

The training weekend is invaluable. Speaking as a prize winner I would say that the experience of the training weekend was more valuable than the prize money.

The people you meet through it are inspiring!
I am shortly going to MT Roraima in Venezuela to make a conservation documentary.

Alistair Linsell – Chemistry – 2009 Runner Up

For researchers to create and maintain barriers between themselves and those who will ultimately support their work – ie the society in which they live – is folly.

Famelab has recently been nationally and internationally preeminent among very few such chances. The competition itself is fun and challenging; the organization is friendly, efficient, and professional; and the people involved helpful and encouraging.

We need more, not fewer, such opportunities and the capital of experience and credibility invested in the Famelab organization could not easily be replaced or re-created.

Martin Coath – Computational Neuroscience – 2007 Reserve Finalist

Following Famelab she received a grant for working with Olympic sports teams and paid research trips to Finland, Estonia and Sri Lanka

Dr Sarah Forbes-Robertson – Molecular Biology – 2009 Finalist

Famelab convinced me to stay in Science. It connected me to people that were interested in putting on talks and shows who were still active in science, and reaffirmed for me that I want to remain a scientist with a high outreach profile, rather than leave science solely to do communications.

Matt Barker – Biophysics – 2009 Finalist

I currently work at the National Marine Aquarium and my employers have recognized my media training from Famelab enabling me to speak to the press and radio when required.

Caroline Johnson – Marine Biology – 2007 Finalist

Famelab was nothing short of a life-changing experience. I received brilliant media training from Malcolm Love, invaluable advice from judges Jim Al-Khalili and Mark Lythgoe,

I have travelled with the British Council to promote science communication abroad, chaired debates and judged debating competitions for the Institute of Ideas.

I have been welcomed into the community of ‘science communication’ - passionate scientists from a range of disciplines who want to share their excitement for their field. Many, such as Lord Winston, happily share their knowledge and experience with Famelabbers.

Peter Zeidman – Artificial Intelligence – 2007 Finalist

FameLab provides a unique set of circumstances for those with science communication potential to meet, build networks and, ultimately, do things they just wouldn't be able to do on their own in the field of science communication as practising scientists.

communicating one's research is a vital part of the scientific process

Three Minute Wonders Channel 4
Tree of Physics Show with Andrew Pontzen and Matt Baker
Writing for The Times and the Guardian

Tom Whyntie – Particle Physics – 2009 WINNER

Without FameLab, I'd probably still just be doing the odd science festival or free talk to small audiences about my acoustics research. Instead, my Physics of Rock Guitar show is reaching tens of thousands of people per year in the UK and attracting large audiences in Europe, Japan and the US, in addition to my regular radio slots and occasional TV appearances.

Mark Lewney – Physics – 2005 WINNER

FameLab meant to me a great opportunity to extend my scientific communication abilities, to come in touch with new people full of energy and enthusiasm for science. I truly feel enriched by many Famelab activities such as training by professional science communicators, participation in the Cheltenham science festival, working on the declaration of science communicators in the Istanbul meeting, etc.
The experience of communicating science to any level of audience had a direct impact on my abilities to present research results. I still remember in the middle of any presentation I make today in front of specialists to include a "YUPI" signal somehow to bring back attention and raise interest - thank you, Steve Measure!

CAMELIA CHIRA Winner FameLab Romania 2008
